title: Darby Allin
text:
Samuel Ratsch (born January 7, 1993), better known by the <a href="ring%20name">ring name</a> Darby Allin, is an American <a href="professional%20wrestler">professional wrestler</a> signed to <a href="All%20Elite%20Wrestling">All Elite Wrestling</a> (AEW), where he is a former and longest-reigning <a href="AEW%20TNT%20Championship">AEW TNT Champion</a>. He is also known for his appearances in <a href="WWNLive">World Wrestling Network</a> promotions, wrestling for <a href="Evolve%20%28professional%20wrestling%29">Evolve</a>.
Early life.
Growing up, Ratsch took part in <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a> and played <a href="American%20football">football</a> as one of his grandfathers played in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a>. He also took part in <a href="amateur%20wrestling">amateur wrestling</a>, but only because he assumed it was <a href="professional%20wrestling">professional wrestling</a>. He later attended a film school in Arizona, dropping out to pursue a career in <a href="skateboarding">skateboarding</a>. Through his connections with Matt Schlager, Ratsch regularly appeared in video clips with his friends on "<a href="Ridiculousness%20%28TV%20series%29">Ridiculousness</a>", until one video was too extreme for the program to air. He also appeared on an episode of "<a href="Sex%20Sent%20Me%20to%20the%20ER">Sex Sent Me to the ER</a>", later admitting in an interview with <a href="Chris%20Van%20Vliet">Chris Van Vliet</a> that the story was fabricated ,as he needed the money. For about three years, Ratsch was <a href="Bohemianism">intentionally homeless</a>.
Professional wrestling career.
Independent circuit (2015–2019).
Ratsch made his professional wrestling debut in late 2014 for Blue Collar Wrestling in Portland, Oregon under the ring name Darby Graves, before changing it to Darby Allin. In late 2017, he wrestled for the <a href="Game%20Changer%20Wrestling">Game Changer Wrestling</a> (GCW) <a href="Professional%20wrestling%20promotion">promotion</a>.
World Wrestling Network (2016–2019).
Allin debuted for <a href="WWNLive">World Wrestling Network</a> at <a href="Evolve%20%28professional%20wrestling%29">Evolve</a> 59 in April 2016, losing to <a href="Ethan%20Page">Ethan Page</a>. At Evolve 74, Allin was defeated via countout by <a href="Brian%20Cage">Brian Cage</a> after Cage had powerslammed Allin over a barricade. Allin made his <a href="Style%20Battle">Style Battle</a> debut in January 2017, losing to <a href="The%20Crist%20Brothers">Dave Crist</a>. Allin made his <a href="Full%20Impact%20Pro">Full Impact Pro</a> debut in early 2017 at FIP Everything Burns, losing a "Fight For All" match. On the same show, Allin, along with <a href="AR%20Fox">AR Fox</a>, Dave Crist and <a href="Sami%20Callihan">Sami Callihan</a> defeated Sammy Guevara, <a href="Dezmond%20Xavier">Dezmond Xavier</a>, <a href="Jason%20Kincaid">Jason Kincaid</a> and Jason Cade. At Evolve 93, he was defeated by <a href="Zema%20Ion">DJZ</a>. in January 2018, Allin faced <a href="Zack%20Sabre%20Jr.">Zack Sabre Jr.</a> for the <a href="Evolve%20Championship">Evolve Championship</a> at EVOLVE 98, in a losing effort.
On August 30, 2018, it was announced that at Evolve 113, Allin would be facing <a href="NXT%20%28WWE%20brand%29">NXT</a> wrestler, the <a href="Velveteen%20Dream">Velveteen Dream</a>. At Evolve 113, Allin was defeated by Dream. At Evolve 116, Allin was defeated by <a href="Mustafa%20Ali%20%28wrestler%29">Mustafa Ali</a>. At Evolve 117, Allin was defeated by <a href="Chris%20Hero">Kassius Ohno</a>. The next night at Evolve 118, Allin was defeated by <a href="Roderick%20Strong">Roderick Strong</a>.
During <a href="WrestleMania%2035">WrestleMania</a> weekend, he wrestled his last match for Evolve at Evolve 125, in a defeat to Anthony Henry. He also wrestled at Amerika Ist Wunderbar, promoted by <a href="Westside%20Xtreme%20Wrestling">Westside Xtreme Wrestling</a> (wXw), and in conjunction with WWN, where he was defeated by Avalanche. The following day at WWN Supershow Mercury Rising, he teamed with his wife <a href="Priscilla%20Kelly">Priscilla Kelly</a>, where they were defeated by <a href="Austin%20Theory">Austin Theory</a> and <a href="Brandi%20Lauren">Brandi Lauren</a>. That same weekend, it was revealed he was going to be ending his three-year relationship with Evolve and WWN.
Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide (2018).
On June 3, 2018, Allin made his <a href="Lucha%20Libre%20AAA%20Worldwide">Lucha Libre AAA Worldwide</a> debut at <a href="Verano%20de%20Esc%C3%A1ndalo%20%282018%29">Verano de Escándalo</a> in a six-way match which was won by <a href="Aero%20Star">Aero Star</a>. Other competitors in the match included <a href="Drago%20%28wrestler%29">Drago</a>, <a href="Sammy%20Guevara">Sammy Guevara</a>, <a href="Australian%20Suicide%20%28wrestler%29">Australian Suicide</a> and <a href="Golden%20Magic">Golden Magic</a>.
Progress Wrestling (2018–2019).
In 2018, Allin wrestled for <a href="Progress%20Wrestling">Progress Wrestling</a> during their American tours. He made his debut for the promotion at Chapter 66: Mardi Graps, held in <a href="Louisiana">Louisiana</a>, in a Thuderbastard match which was won by <a href="Jeff%20Cobb">Jeff Cobb</a>. He later appeared on day five of the Coast to Coast Tour, teaming with Jack Sexsmith and <a href="Toni%20Storm">Toni Storm</a> in a six-person tag team match.
On March 14, 2019, Allin was announced as a participant in the Super Strong Style 16. At the event, he was defeated by Paul Robinson. On day two, he teamed with Chris Ridgeway and Lucky Kid in a six-man lucha rules tag team match, defeating Artemis Spencer, Chris Brookes and <a href="DJZ">DJZ</a>. On day three, Allin took part in a scramble match, which was won by Brookes.
All Elite Wrestling (2019–present).
Initial appearances (2019–2020).
On April 12, 2019, Allin signed with the newly launched <a href="All%20Elite%20Wrestling">All Elite Wrestling</a> (AEW). He made his AEW debut at the <a href="Fyter%20Fest%20%282019%29">Fyter Fest</a> event on June 29, where he wrestled <a href="Cody%20Rhodes">Cody</a> to a time-limit draw. The following month at <a href="Fight%20for%20the%20Fallen%20%282019%29">Fight for the Fallen</a>, Allin teamed with <a href="Joey%20Janela">Joey Janela</a> and <a href="Jimmy%20Havoc">Jimmy Havoc</a> in a losing effort to <a href="Shawn%20Spears">Shawn Spears</a>, <a href="Maxwell%20Jacob%20Friedman">MJF</a> and <a href="Sammy%20Guevara">Sammy Guevara</a>. After the match, the three men would blame each other for the loss and brawl backstage. Subsequently, a three-way match was arranged for the <a href="All%20Out%20%282019%29">All Out</a> <a href="pay-per-view">pay-per-view</a> on August 31, which Havoc won.
In October, Allin entered contention for the <a href="AEW%20World%20Championship">AEW World Championship</a>, and would challenge <a href="Chris%20Jericho">Chris Jericho</a> for the championship on the October 16 episode of "<a href="AEW%20Dynamite">Dynamite</a>", but lost. At <a href="AEW%20Bash%20at%20the%20Beach">Bash at the Beach</a> on January 15, 2020, Allin competed in a four-man tournament for number one contendership to the AEW World Championship, but lost in the first round to <a href="Pac%20%28wrestler%29">Pac</a>. Following this, Allin began a feud with Sammy Guevara, an ally of Jericho's. The two faced at <a href="Revolution%20%282020%29">Revolution</a> on February 29, where Allin emerged victorious. In April, Allin competed in a tournament to crown to the inaugural holder of the <a href="AEW%20TNT%20Championship">AEW TNT Championship</a>. After defeating Guevara in the first round, he was eliminated after losing to Cody in the semi-finals.
On May 23, Allin participated in the first-ever <a href="Casino%20Ladder%20Match">Casino Ladder Match</a> at <a href="Double%20or%20Nothing%20%282020%29">Double or Nothing</a> in a losing effort as the match was won by the debuting <a href="Brian%20Cage">Brian Cage</a>. After an absence, Allin returned at <a href="Fight%20for%20the%20Fallen%20%282020%29">Fight for the Fallen</a> on July 15, attacking Cage with a skateboard. On the July 29 episode of "Dynamite", Allin teamed with AEW World Champion <a href="Jon%20Moxley">Jon Moxley</a> to defeat Cage and <a href="Ricky%20Starks">Ricky Starks</a> in a <a href="tornado%20tag%20team%20match">tornado tag team match</a>, with Allin subsequently being granted a match against Moxley for the championship. The match took place on the following week's episode of "Dynamite", where Allin was defeated. On August 29, a 30-second black-and-white segment of Allin doing a promo walking down a forest road with thumbtacks in his back, and then proceeding to climb up to the top of a bridge and jump off it into a river. On September 5, Allin competed in the 21-man <a href="Casino%20Battle%20Royale">Casino Battle Royale</a> at <a href="All%20Out%20%282020%29">All Out</a>, but was eliminated by Cage. On the September 30 episode of "Dynamite", Allin faced off against nemesis Ricky Starks in a winning effort.
TNT Champion and partnership with Sting (2020–present).
On November 7, 2020, Allin won the <a href="AEW%20TNT%20Championship">AEW TNT Championship</a> at <a href="Full%20Gear%20%282020%29">Full Gear</a> by defeating <a href="Cody%20Rhodes">Cody Rhodes</a>. Rhodes and Allin would afterwards unite in a feud with Team <a href="Tazz">Taz</a>. On the November 18, 2020, <a href="Will%20Hobbs%20%28wrestler%29">Will Hobbs</a> turned <a href="Heel%20%28professional%20wrestling%29">heel</a> after assisting <a href="Tazz">Taz</a>, <a href="Brian%20Cage">Brian Cage</a> and <a href="Ricky%20Starks">Ricky Starks</a> in attacking both Allin and Rhodes. On the December 2, 2020 special <a href="Winter%20Is%20Coming%20%282020%29">Winter Is Coming</a>, Allin and Rhodes teamed up to defeat Hobbs and Starks, and after the match, <a href="Sting%20%28wrestler%29">Sting</a> made his AEW debut and ran off Team Taz when they jumped Allin and Rhodes, after which Allin and Sting stared each other down. On January 13, 2021 special <a href="AEW%20New%20Year%27s%20Smash">New Year's Smash Night 2</a>, Allin made his first successful defense against <a href="Brian%20Cage">Brian Cage</a>. On January 21, it was announced that Allin and Sting would be taking on Team Taz's Ricky Starks and Brian Cage in a street fight at <a href="Revolution%20%282021%29">Revolution</a>. At Revolution, Allin and Sting were victorious over Team Taz in a cinematic pre-taped match. On March 10, 2021, Allin successfully defended the <a href="AEW%20TNT%20Championship">AEW TNT Championship</a> against <a href="Scorpio%20Sky">Scorpio Sky</a>. 
On March 17, Allin issued an open challenge to the <a href="The%20Dark%20Order">Dark Order</a> as a tribute to the late "greatest TNT Champion of all time" <a href="Brodie%20Lee">Brodie Lee</a>, which was responded by <a href="John%20Silver%20%28wrestler%29">John Silver</a>. The next week, Allin defeated Silver to retain the title. He made further successful defenses of the TNT Championship against JD Drake on the April 7 episode of Dynamite and against <a href="Andy%20Williams%20%28guitarist%29">The Butcher</a> at AEW's first non-televised event two days later, while also starting a feud with <a href="Matt%20Hardy">Matt Hardy</a>. On April 21, Allin successfully defended the AEW TNT Championship against <a href="Jungle%20Boy%20%28wrestler%29">Jungle Boy</a>. On April 28, Allin successfully defended the AEW TNT Championship against Dark Order’s 10, before being attacked by <a href="Scorpio%20Sky">Scorpio Sky</a> and <a href="Ethan%20Page">Ethan Page</a>. Sky and Page would then themselves be attacked by <a href="Lance%20Archer">Lance Archer</a> and Dark Order’s 10, saving Sting and Allin in the process.
On the May 12 episode of "Dynamite", Allin lost the TNT Championship to <a href="Rusev%20%28wrestler%29">Miro</a>, ending his record-setting reign at 186 days. At <a href="Double%20or%20Nothing%20%282021%29">Double or Nothing</a> Allin teamed up with Sting to defeat the team of Scorpio Sky and Ethan Page. He defeated Page in AEW's first ever Coffin Match at Night 1 of <a href="Fyter%20Fest%20%282021%29">Fyter Fest</a>, putting an end to their feud. 
On the August 20 episode of "<a href="AEW%20Rampage">AEW Rampage</a>" titled <a href="AEW%20The%20First%20Dance">The First Dance</a>, Allin was challenged to a pay-per-view match at <a href="All%20Out%20%282021%29">All Out</a> by <a href="CM%20Punk">CM Punk</a>, who had made his AEW debut after an absence of seven years from professional wrestling. Allin lost the match to Punk.
Professional wrestling style and persona.
Ratsch incorporates many elements of his personal life into his wrestling persona; a longtime fan of <a href="punk%20rock">punk rock</a>, Ratsch's current ring name Darby Allin is derived from the frontman of the <a href="Germs%20%28band%29">Germs</a>, <a href="Darby%20Crash">Darby Crash</a>, and the transgressive musician <a href="GG%20Allin">GG Allin</a>, while his signature face paint, in which he paints half his face in a skull design, is born out of Ratsch's sentiment that he's been "half dead" since surviving the car accident in which his uncle died. Another aspect of Ratsch's background he incorporates into his wrestling is <a href="skateboarding">skateboarding</a>, as he rides a skateboard to the ring during his entrance, and occasionally uses it as a weapon. Previous to his career taking off in professional wrestling, Ratsch also sought to be a professional skateboarder. Ratsch was initially hesitant to integrate his skateboarding into his pro wrestling work, fearing that both the wrestling and skateboarding fandoms would perceive it as inauthentic; however, he overcame his doubts following encouragement and advice from Chris Jericho.
Personal life.
Ratsch lives a <a href="straight%20edge">straight edge</a> lifestyle, which he adopted in part due to a traumatic incident during his childhood: as a five-year-old, Ratsch was a passenger in a car when his uncle was <a href="driving%20while%20intoxicated">driving while intoxicated</a>; his uncle lost control of the vehicle and was killed in the resulting crash. 
On November 21, 2018, Ratsch married fellow wrestler <a href="Priscilla%20Kelly">Priscilla Kelly</a>. On August 10, 2020, the couple announced they were divorcing. In December 2020, Kelly confirmed during an appearance on Vickie Guerrero's "Excuse Me" podcast that they were no longer married, but still remain friends.
